In Julia, Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

You can define your `show` method in Julia by using the `@sprintf` function which allows you to format numbers and strings. Here is an example:

```julia
struct FloatWithUnits
    value::Float64
    unit::String
end

function Base.show(io::IO, fwu::FloatWithUnits)
    print(io, @sprintf("%g %s", fwu.value, fwu.unit))
end
```
In this example, `fwu.value` is the value of your number and `fwu.unit` is the unit that you want to append to it. The `%g` in `@sprintf` is used to automatically choose between scientific notation (for very large or small numbers) and decimal format (for normal numbers), depending on the context. You can change this to a specific format if needed.

This will now print your `FloatWithUnits` as "1.8 meters" when printed.
